result.execSummary:
The defendant was charged with both OWI (5th) and Operating w/ PAC (5th). The defendant was found guilty of OWI (5th) and the other charge, Operating w/ PAC (5th) was dismissed by the court.

  • James M. Upthegrove was found guilty of OWI (5th), a class H felony, Wisconsin Statutes 346.63(1)(a).
  • James M. Upthegrove was found guilty of Bail Jumping-Felony, a class H felony, Wisconsin Statutes 946.49(1)(b).

Charge(s) in this case were read in to this or other case(s). A "read in" charge is a charge that is dismissed as part of a plea agreement, however:

  • The defendant agrees to have the court consider the charge(s) when sentencing for another crime, under Wis. Stats. 973.20(1g)(b); and
  • The defendant cannot be prosecuted for these charge(s) in the future.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

Dated 07/29/19 from Atty Mark Schoenfeldt to Court regarding the State not filing a response to the defendant's motion nor a request for an extension of time to file. Atty Schoenfeldt requests the Court enter an Order granting the defendant's motion.

Regarding Defendant's Motion for Post-Conviction Relief
-It is ordered: 1. The State shall file and exchange any response to the defendant's Motion for Post-Conviction Relief on or before July 26, 2019. 2. Replies to any responses shall be filed and exchanged on or before August 9, 2019. 3. In addition to filing their affidavits and pleadings electronically, the parties must provide the Court with a paper copy of all motion filings. 4. The Court will review the submissions and render a written decision or, in the alternative, set a hearing if the Court determines oral argument is necessary.

outlining deadlines from motion hearing held 5/30/18 (see order for details)

(Case called at 2:03 PM)
Defendant James M. Upthegrove appears in custody with Attorney Mark A. Schoenfeldt.  Loralee Clark appeared for the State of Wisconsin.
Defendant indicates he provided information to Attorney Schoenfeldt regarding the death in the family that resulted in him missing the last hearing.  Attorney Schoenfeldt did not file proof of death/funeral proceedings with the Court as instructed.  Court will hold issue in abeyance.  Defendant wishes to testify and is sworn.  Defendant advised of right to remain silent and right to testify.  Court accepts defendant's waiver of right to remain silent.  Direct examination by Attorney Schoenfeldt of Defendant James Upthegrove.  Defendant indicates he had wanted to file a motion challenging the stop of the vehicle, but that Attorney Bahnson did not file motion and had indicated that she would withdraw if defendant wanted to pursue it.  Defendant states he wanted to get out of jail and into Huber so he decided to go ahead with the plea, despite wanting to file the motion to suppress.  Cross examination by State.  Defendant understood that a new attorney could take over the case and review the motion to suppress.  Re-direct by Attorney Schoenfeldt.  Defendant believed that even if the suppression motion was not filed, that he was still entitled to the refusal hearing.  Court clarifies that defendant thought that if the suppression motion could still be filed at the refusal hearing, and if successful at the refusal hearing, overturn the plea in the criminal case.  
(2:32- Defendant steps down from stand)  Attorney Schoenfeldt explains the position of the defendant for wanting to file a motion to challenge the stop.  State argues that this motion hearing is in regard to the post-conviction motion, not the motion to challenge the legality of the stop.  State requests a transcript of Attorney Bahnson's testimony be prepared so the Court can compare that to the testimony of the defendant today.  
Court orders Attorney Schoenfeldt provide written argument by June 22, 2018 at 5:00 PM.  State's response due by July 13, 2018 at 5:00 PM.  Reply due July 27, 2018 at 5:00 PM.  State and Defense to split cost of ordering transcripts from previous motion hearing, as well as today's motion hearing.
for transport for a hearing on 5/30/18 at 1:45 pm
